title: Tuesday, 3rd May, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Hi there

PM

Nice weekend?

PM

Extended weekend

11:01 am
BE

Hm.

PM

Suppose we can run this chap as our pic today

PM

11:01 am
PM

Craig Wright

PM

Bitcoin trickster

PM

Who conned the BBC into believing that he is Satoshi

11:02 am

Seriously. Any news quality control at the BBC on this?

PM

PM

Truly idiotic

11:03 am

ll good fun for us of course

PM

Izy in particular

11:03 am

I think we should say these are personal views, to be clear, PM. Not an editorial line.

eh?

PM

I'm stating hard facts Bryce

11:04 am

PM

PM

http://www.bbc.co....echnology-36185267

Toe curling

11:05 am
PM

What you think he's for real??

BE

No. I have my own theories. But they're no better than anyone else's theories. Worse, probably.

BE

I'm not predisposed to believe the the idea that Satoshi is an Australian Simon Cowell lookalike with a 2300-word terms and conditions page on his Wordpress site.

11:06 am
BE

http://www.drcraig....net/terms-of-use/

11:07 am
PM

omg smile

BE

And "Satoshi" was actually a small team at the PGP Corporation, probably run by Hal Finney, who's dead.

PM

So you are of the opinion that the BBC was duped?

11:08 am
BE

I'm of the opinion that they have, but my opinions are worthless. My speculation's no better and probably considerably worse than anyone else's.

PM

Well, given that all the credulous coverage of Bitcoin means the stupid thing has gone mainstream -- and think we need to call out the fruitloops here

PM

That's what we do, yeah?

11:10 am
PM

We call frauds frauds

BE

Oh, there's no shortage of fruitloops. But there also seem to be lots of sincere fruitloops around here.

BE

Which might or might not include Doctor Craig Wright himself. Dunno.

11:11 am

Anyway, back on Planet Eart

BE

h.

undefined

11:16 am
PM

Highlights

· Net revenue £483.6 million (-20%)

· Underlying profit before tax £162.9 million (-40%)

· Underlying earnings per share 9.6p (-41%)

BE

Well, as we've said quite a lot, Aberdeen's problem isn't just EM.

BE

It's that its funds are rubbish at EM.

hehehe

11:17 am

PM

The divided is uncovered

PM

Welcome to ML

11:18 am
BE

PBT misses consensus.

BE

And another -- get this! -- £7.6bn of outflows.

BE

EPS down 41%!

11:20 am
BE

And what we have to emphasise is that outflows are slowing a bit.

BE

Results, while awful, aren't that much more awful than consensus.

BE

Though the cost savings flagged up don't seem to be particularly new.

11:21 am
BE

When you've erased 41% of earnings, is it normal to think that 41% of costs might be on the line too? Or do I misunderstand fund management, like I misunderstand so many things?

BE

Here's RBC.

BE

Cost control: Aberdeen today announced £70MM of annualised cost
efficiencies to be achieved through “review of strategic outsourcing
and supplier arrangements, as well as process improvements across
operations and other support functions.” According to Aberdeen, the
benefit of these savings will be “approximately £50 million” in FY17,
with the “full benefit” realized in FY18. Our forecasts already assume
a reduction of £118MM in real terms from Aberdeen’s pro-forma FY15
cost base through FY18, which includes the £50MM in cost reductions
already announced in Nov-15. Based on Aberdeen’s cost guidance, our
expectations for cost reductions appear too optimistic.

11:22 am
BE

Outlook: Despite the Q/Q improvement in both overall and equity net
flows in the quarter to 31-Mar, Aberdeen does not expect a “dramatic
improvement in new business flows … in the short term.” Aberdeen
envisages that “markets may continue to provide challenges in the short
term.”
Conclusion: Mixed. While flows (both total and equity) showed another
quarter of improvement (we expect flows to show a continued gradual
improvement), we believe this is counterbalanced by the following
negatives: (1) the previously announced costs savings of £50MM are
largely accounted for by consensus and the additional £20MM is unlikely
to excite the market, and (2) despite AUM being in line with our forecasts,
revenue missed, indicating that the revenue yield has deteriorated more
quickly than we anticipated. There is a presentation today at 9.30am;
we will update the market afterwards with the key points. Valuation:
Aberdeen trades at 10.7x CY16E EBITDA (sector: 10.1x) and 14.9x CY16E
EPS (sector: 14.9x).

BE

And Barclays.

BE

We believe expectations were high for Aberdeen Asset Mgt going into these 1H results around signs of improvement in flow momentum and update on cost rationalizations. This is due to the strong share outperformance ytd (up 3% vs most UK Asset Mgrs down double-digit % and FTSE Allshare flat). On flow outlook management appear pretty cautious and the cost rationalization increase to £70m (from greater than £50m previously) is only in line with our expectations. In terms of P&L, 1H 16 underlying PBT of £162.9m is -1% light on Barclays estimate of £164.8m. Outflows of -£7.6bn in the qtr (vs -£9bn for the previous qtr and Barclays estimate of -£7bn) suggest some improvement in momentum but progress is likely to be slow. We have warned that Aberdeen’s problems are much bigger than just EM/Macro sentiment driven and today’s results confirm that, in our opinion. The group has lost a further -£3.5bn of outflows in the qtr from Equities. GEM Equities actually records a small inflow in the qtr of £66m and Asia-Pac an outflow of -£1.4bn. But the largest outflows are still from Global Equities (-£2bn) where performance has been poor. In addition the group has lost -£2.7bn from Fixed Income in the qtr (mainly from the US desk) and -£2.4bn from Aberdeen Solutions. Management’s outlook statement is pretty cautious highlighting that there is encouragement for the longer-term but they envisage that markets may continue to provide challenges in the short-term. Whilst they highlighting attracting interest in their broader product range they do not indicate that outflows are likely to be curtailed any time soon. Interim DPS as expected is in line yoy at 7.5p with nothing indicated on intentions for FY DPS. Shares trading at 14.8x 2017E PE.

Insurance mentioned.

11:31 am
RSA Insurance Group PLC (RSA:LSE): Last: 471.50, up 12.4 (+2.70%), High: 487.40, Low: 470.90, Volume: 950.63k
BE

....... Which is on a Barclays upgrade.

BE

RSA has set out its ambition to close the gap to the best in class players in each of its core markets, UK, Scandinavia and Canada by 2018. While we acknowledge that it is rare for a mid of the pack insurer to become a “best in class” insurer, we do believe RSA has set out a realistic plan to get there. RSA’s ambition is to have a combined ratio of 94% or lower in the UK and Canada, and 85% or below in Scandinavia. We believe there is significant upside even if the company is only partially successful, and we revise our price target of 545p is based on the company on getting half way to its targets. With 19% upside to our revised price target of 545p, coupled with a 3% FY16 yield, we upgrade our rating to Overweight.

Base case – 19% upside: We see significant upside to RSA if it progresses towards its targets, even if it does not hit its ambitions by 2018. Our base case assumes RSA gets half way to its targets, with a 2018 EPS of 48p and a combined ratio of 92.8%.

Bull case – 44% upside: RSA is effectively aiming to get its combined ratios to the same level as Aviva in the UK and Canada, and to Tryg, Top and Gjedsidige’s levels in Scandinavia. If the company is successful in achieving this ambition by 2018, it could deliver a combined ratio of 91% and EPS of 57p, and in our view would justify a valuation of 661p, implying 42% upside. This is the basis of our upside case valuation.

Capital structure can be optimised: RSA’s solvency capital structure fully utilizes Tier 1 and Tier 2 debt. RSA also has greater than £250m of potential DTAs that could partly replace expensive (£500m 9.375% Tier 2 debt). We believe the company will refinance this expensive debt in 2016, reducing interest cost by c£20m with no impact on Solvency.

Special dividends to resume in 2018: RSA was at one time a favourite of income funds, and we see no reason why it can’t reclaim this crown in the future. In the short term, restructuring costs, pension contributions and the impact of the pull to par will restrain dividends, but we expect special dividends to start by 2018, with a yield of 6.6% in 2018, increasing to 8.1% in 2019.

PM

BE

Admiral Group PLC (ADM:LSE): Last: 1,901, up 44 (+2.37%), High: 1,942, Low: 1,900, Volume: 292.07k
11:35 am
BE

BE

Macquarie's very good insurance team wrote this last week.

11:37 am
BE

Upgrade Direct to Neutral on dividend support
Since the 2015 results in March, Direct Line has noticeably underperformed its
peers, falling 8% on a total return basis while Admiral has fallen just 0.7%.
The current valuation now indicates a c.6% yield p.a. over the next three years,
on our forecasts. Without special dividends this yield remains at more than 4%
across the period, which we believe provides investors with ample income
returns in this market and limits downside risks.
Dividend expected to support Direct Line valuation
Direct Line’s management have recently guided that the move from the Solvency
II standard formula to an internal model will not result in a “step change” in
capital. Admiral on the other hand has indicated excess capital returns “in the
region of £150m - £200m” over three years (50p-67p per share) from its
transition from the Solvency II standard formula to an internal model.
We expect that this difference in capital guidance has driven Direct Line’s recent
underperformance. Nevertheless, as we expect that Direct Line has enough
excess capital to make a modest special dividend to shareholders at 1H 2016,
we now see downside risk as limited at Direct Line.
Consensus is has yet to factor in falling profits at peers
Consensus EPS reveals that the market now perceives Direct Line as having
reached peak profitability, whereas its peers are estimated to sustain or even
grow their current high profits.
We expect that the whole sector has reached peak profitability and that
consensus will also factor this in for Direct Line’s peers. Consequently, we
believe that many of Direct Line’s peers will experience similar
underperformance through 2016.
Motor Insurance sub-sector remains expensive
As high profits from 2011-2013 run off and with no stand-out performers for the
2014-2015 periods, we believe that the whole sub-sector is overvalued, with
Admiral particularly highly valued.
We expect that with flat prices in1Q 2016, claims inflation eroding current year
margins and expected declining reserve release, earnings will fall.
As such, we upgrade Direct Line to Neutral (from Underperform) with an
unchanged target price of 335p and reiterate our Underperform
recommendation for Admiral with an unchanged target price of 1510p.

Direct Line Insurance Group PLC (DLG:LSE): Last: 367.30, up 5.4 (+1.49%), High: 373.30, Low: 364.00, Volume: 2.26m
